S Škocjanskim zatokom bo še naprej upravljalo društvo za opazovanje in proučevanje ptic
06 Nov 2019, 15:16 by STA

Z naravnim rezervatom Škocjanski zatok bo še naprej upravljalo Društvo za opazovanje in proučevanje ptic Slovenije, ki je z njim upravljalo tudi minulih 20 let. Aneks h koncesijski pogodbi za upravljanje sta danes podpisala minister za okolje in prostor Simon Zajc ter predsednik društva Rudolf Tekavčič.



Foto: Zdravko Primožič/FPA

LJUBLJANA > “Podlaga za podpis je bil sklep vlade, s katerim je ta odločila, da se društvu koncesija po 20 letih uspešnega upravljanja Naravnega rezervata Škocjanski zatok podaljša za nadaljnjih 10 let,” so sporočili z ministrstva, ki je vladi predlagalo podaljšanje koncesije.
Po pojasnilih Simona Zajca so podaljšanje predlagali zaradi dobrih rezultatov. “Veseli me predvsem to, da je bil z obnovo dosežen cilj - to je ugodno stanje varovanih rastlinskih in živalskih vrst in habitatov. Naravni rezervat je namreč prav zaradi svoje pestrosti izjemno pomemben,” je poudaril.
Ponosni na infrastrukturo
Zajca veseli tudi, da je bila v zadnjih letih zgrajena infrastruktura, ki omogoča, da ljudje obiščejo ta rezervat na način, ki omogoča ohranjanje naravnih danosti.
“Na društvu smo še posebej ponosni na uspešnost obnove in upravljanja Škocjanskega zatoka, kjer na 122 hektarjev velikem območju ohranjamo izjemno biotsko raznovrstnost. Od več kot 1400 evidentiranih živalskih in rastlinskih vrst je kar 254 vrst ptic, kar je več kot 65 odstotkov vseh pri nas opaženih ptic. Tukaj je denimo v Sloveniji prvič začela gnezditi rjava čaplja. Tudi stanje habitatov je zelo ugodno, predvsem tistih, ki so na seznamu Natura 2000,” pa je dejal predsednik društva Tekavčič.
Društvo je leta 1999 postalo prvi koncesionar za upravljanje zavarovanega območja narave v Sloveniji, in sicer leto prej razglašenega Naravnega rezervata Škocjanski zatok.
20 let sodelovanja
V teh 20 letih je dosledno in z vestnostjo dobrega gospodarja izpolnjevalo vse pogodbene obveznosti, so navedli na ministrstvu in med glavni rezultati izpostaviti predvsem obnovo in habitatno ureditev Škocjanskega zatoka, ki je skupaj z načrtovanjem in pripravami potekala v letih 2000-2008 ter zgraditev infrastrukture za obisk naravnega rezervata v letih 2014-2016.
Z zgraditvijo objektov je bila uresničena ureditev naravnega rezervata odprtega za javnost, delo z obiskovalci pa je uspešno steklo po odprtju objektov in naravnega rezervata marca 2016.

The Skocjan Bay will continue to be managed by the Bird Observation and Study Society
06 Nov 2019, 15:16 by STA

The Skocjanski zatok Nature Reserve will continue to be managed by the Slovenian Birdwatching and Research Society, which has managed it for the past 20 years. The annex to the management concession contract was signed today by the Minister of the Environment and Spatial Planning Simon Zajc and the president of the Rudolf Tekavčič Society.



Photo: Zdravko Primozic / FPA

LJUBLJANA> “The basis for the signature was the government's decision deciding to extend the concession to the association after 20 years of successful management of the Skocjanski zatok Nature Reserve for another 10 years,” a ministry said, proposing the government to extend the concession.
According to Simon Zajc, the extension was proposed for good results. “I am particularly pleased that the objective of restoration has been achieved - that is, the favorable status of protected plant and animal species and habitats. Because of its diversity, the nature reserve is extremely important, ”he emphasized.
Proud of infrastructure
Zajc is also pleased that the infrastructure has been built in recent years to allow people to visit this reserve in a way that preserves natural resources.
“At the Society, we are particularly proud of the success of the Škocjan Strait restoration and management, where we maintain exceptional biodiversity in 122 hectares of large area. Of the more than 1,400 recorded animal and plant species, as many as 254 are bird species, which is more than 65 percent of all birds observed in our country. For example, the brown heron started breeding in Slovenia for the first time. The state of the habitats is also very favorable, especially those included in the Natura 2000 list, ”said the president of the Tekavčič Society.
In 1999, the Company became the first concessionaire for the management of the protected nature area in Slovenia, the year previously declared the Nature Reserve Škocjanski zatok.
20 years of collaboration
During these 20 years, the contractor has consistently and conscientiously fulfilled all contractual obligations, said the ministry and highlighted among the main results the restoration and habitat management of the Škocjan Strait, which, together with the planning and preparation, took place in 2000-2008 and the construction of infrastructure for visit to the nature reserve in 2014-2016.
The construction of the facilities resulted in the establishment of a nature reserve open to the public, and work with visitors has been successful since the opening of the facilities and the nature reserve in March 2016.
